predicted_summary: 400 years of African-American History Commission Act - Establishes the 400 years and the membership of the commission to plan, develop, and execute programs and activities to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the arrival of African Americans in the United States, and to promote educational and public awareness of the history of the enslaved Africans, including the role of African American women in the development of the American community.Requires the Secretary to appoint: (1) one member of the commission to be an employee of the National Park Service; (2) two members to be appointed by the Secretary after considering the recommendations of the Secretary of the smithsonian institution; and (3) three commission members.(This measure has not been amended since it was reported to the Senate on June 1, 2017. (Sec. 1) This bill directs the Department of Education to plan, develop, and implement programs and activities appropriate for the commemoration of the 1619 arrival of African Americans in the United States.African African American History Commission (the Commission) shall: (1) establish and implement a plan for the commemoration of the African American Home Study Study which shall include the development of a national commemoration plan, according to prescribed guidelines; (2) develop appropriate programs, projects, and activities to commemorate the home study of African Americans who were present at the arrival of African aliens in the United States; (3) ensure that the commemoration provides a lasting legacy and long-term public benefit by assisting in program development and development of appropriate programs; and (4) help ensure that observances of the commemoration are inclusive and appropriately recognize the experiences and heritage of all individuals present at such arrival. (Sec. 5) Directs the Commission to: (1) develop a strategic plan and annual goals and objectives to ensure the commemoration's effectiveness; (2) establish an advisory committee to advise the Commission on development of the plan and activities; (3) seek to enter into agreements with private sector and other organizations, institutions, and individuals to assist in the development and implementation of programs and projects to carry out this Act; (4) annually elect members of the Commission; and (5) establish a Board of Trustees for the Commission, which shall advise and consult with the Commission regarding the preparation and activities of the Committee. ( Sec. 6) Requires the Commission: (1) to submit annual reports to the Congress; and (2) to the Secretary of the Interior, to the appropriate congressional committees, and to the President, within three years of its establishment.Authorizes the Commission to make grants, enter into contracts, and procure supplies, services, and property. Authorizes Commission members and employees to make gifts, bequests, or devises for the benefit of the Commission.Requires the Commission to: (1) serve without compensation; and (2) pay its members without compensation other than the compensation received as an officer or employee of the Federal Government. Authorizes the Commission, without regard to civil service laws, to nominate an executive director to enable it to perform its duties.Prohibits the rate of pay for executive directors and other personnel from exceeding that for level v of the executive schedule. Provides for detail of government employees (including federal and state employees) to assist the Commission.Requires the Commission shall prepare a strategic plan and submit to Congress a final report that contains: (1) a summary of the Commission's activities; (2) a final accounting of funds received and expended; and (3) findings and recommendations.This bill terminates the National Commission on the Arts and the Humanities (Commission). The Commission's documents and materials must be transferred to the National Archives or another appropriate federal entity.

predicted_summary: franked mail savings Act - Amends the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 1991 to establish an official mass mailing allowance (thus, a franked mass mailing) for each member of the House of Representatives.Sets forth requirements for congressional mail standards (including a requirement for such standards to be consistent with the standards of the Federal Communications Commission (FCC)). Requires a member of the House of Representatives to submit a sample of the mail matter involved to the House Committee on House Mailing Standards for an advisory opinion to whether a proposed mass mailing is in compliance with such standards.Amends the Rules of the House of Representatives to: (1) prohibit a member or his staff from mailing any mass mailing during a session of Congress, unless such mailing is specifically authorized by a resolution adopted by the House; and (2) require that the information required to be included in such quarterly report be: (1) the number of pieces of mail sent by each member in each session, as well as the amount charged against the member's official mass mailing allowance; and (3) available to the public for review and copying any matter submitted to the Commission.Prohibits a member of the House of Representatives or the Senate, for purposes of the legislative branch, from: (1) sending or receiving mails or other communications from a member or staff member which relates solely to a member's official duties; or (2) using the official name or address of any other member or employee of the Member of Congress.Amends the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 1991 to reduce the allocation of mail allowance to not more than three (currently, two) full-time members of the House of Representatives.
summary_generated: Franked Mail Savings Act - Amends the Legislative Branch Appropriations Act, 1991 to revise the rules for the Official Mass Mailing Allowance for Members of the House of Representatives. Declares that such Allowance shall be available only for postage for any mass mailing sent by a Member as franked mail and shall be available, in a session of Congress, in an amount not to exceed the total amount allocated to such Member in such session. Prohibits transfers to or from such Allowance. <n>Provides that for purposes of such Allowance: (1) the Official Mass Mailing Allowance of any Member shall be treated separately from the Official Mail Allowance of any other official mail sent by such Member; and (2) otherwise applicable law relating to mass mailings sent by a Member shall continue to govern such mass mailings. <n>Prohibits a mass mailing from being sent during any session that begins in an even-numbered calendar year, and requires a Member to submit a sample of the mail matter involved to the House Commission on Congressional Mailing Standards for an advisory opinion as to whether such proposed mailing is in compliance with applicable provisions of law, rule, or regulation. <n>Requires the House Commission on Congressional Mailing Standards to establish procedures under which there shall be made available to the public for review and copying any matter submitted to

predicted_summary: flight 93 national memorial Act - Directs the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to develop a plan for the long-term management, management, and preservation of the site of Flight 93 at the Pentagon, Pennsylvania.Designates the site in stonycreek township, somerset County, Pennsylvania, where United Airlines flight 93 crashed on September 11, 2001, as a unit of the National Park System. Establishes the United Airlines Flight 93 Advisory Commission to assist in the development of plans for the memorial.Flight 93 Advisory Commission - Establishes in the National Park System the Flight 93 Memorial at the crash site to honor the passengers and crewmembers of flight 93.Requires the commission to: (1) meet at the call of the chairperson or a majority of the members at least quarterly; (2) meet not less than quarterly; (3) publish notice of meetings and an agenda for the meetings in newspapers in and around these counties; and (4) select a chairperson from among the members.National Park Memorial Establishment Act - Directs the Secretary of the Interior to establish a commission to: (1) advise the Secretary on the boundaries of the memorial; (2) develop a management plan for it; and (3) involve the public in the memorial planning and design. Terminates the commission ten years after enactment of this Act.Establishes in Pennsylvania the Flight 93 Memorial Fund, to be administered by the Secretary of the Treasury., for the purpose of receiving donations to carry out this Act and to be used for educational and outreach activities.
summary_generated: Flight 93 National Memorial Act - Establishes as a unit of the National Park System a memorial at the site in Stonycreek Township, Somerset County, Pennsylvania, to honor the passengers and crewmembers of United Airlines Flight 93.

predicted_summary: Patients' Formulary Rights Act of 1999 - Amends the Public Health Service Act, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), and the Internal Revenue Code to prohibit a group health plan and a health insurance issuer offering group coverage from using a formulary unless the plan or issuer: (1) notifies participants, beneficiaries, and enrollees, prior to initial enrollment or coverage, and makes available at any time to health care professionals who prescribe prescription drugs under the plan the formulary or coverage of information described in the above; (2) notifies such individuals of the plan's or issuer's availability of such formulary information, including the effect of the formularies and therapeutic substitution of covered drugs; and (3) notifies them, as well as the health care provider, of the prescription drug coverage of such individual and the person who prescribes such drug.Sets forth a list of the prescription drug coverage for which a nonformulary drug may be substituted for a prescription drug.<n> Directs the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to establish a formulary for the Federal Prescription Drug Formulary (PDF), which shall include: (1) the drugs that are the most commonly prescribed drugs in the United States, and (2) the drugs with the highest average dispensing fees. Requires the formulary to disclose to each participant, beneficiary, or enrollee the extent to which therapeutic substitution may be made for each drug.Group Health Insurance Coverage Act - Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to require a group health plan to provide coverage for outpatient prescription drugs without regard to whether a plan or issuer limits the particular drugs for which coverage is available.Amends the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to prohibit a group health plan from using a formulary unless the plan issuer: (1) notifies participants, beneficiaries, and enrollees prior to initial enrollment or coverage of the formulary; and (2) notifies the group health coverage enrollees, participants, and beneficiaries of the plan's or issuer's formulary or other coverage options.Makes information about prescription drug coverage under a group health plan or coverage: (1) available at any time to health care professionals who prescribe prescription drugs under the plan; (2) available to the public at public or private group health offices or through a toll-free telephone number; (3) available at certain times of the year to those who prescribe covered prescription drugs; and (4) available to a participant or beneficiary who is provided coverage for a prescription drug at the time it is removed from the formulary, to permit the individual to continue to have the drug prescribed for treatment of the same condition for which it was previously prescribed.Amends the Public Health Service Act, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), and the Internal Revenue Code to require group health plans to provide: (1) coverage for prescription drugs without regard to whether or not they are covered under a formulary; (2) copayments and other cost-sharing for nonformulary drugs; and (3) access to prescription drugs for a patient who can have a prescription filled as written (rather than subject to therapeutic substitution).Amends the Internal Revenue Code to set forth standards for the use of formularies and therapeutic substitution. (Sec. 9812 and Applies such standards to Medicare Advantage plans and coverage offered in the individual market.Requires a plan to notify participants and beneficiaries, and the health care professionals who prescribe drugs under the plan, prior to initial enrollment or coverage of any formulary changes. Requires an issuer of a formulary to: (1) make available at any time information on the original formulary plus the additional prescription drug coverage, coverage, or pricing information for any covered drug; and (2) notify the plan or a participant or beneficiary of any changes in coverage.Prohibits a group plan from taking any action that would result in: (1) denying coverage for a prescription drug because it is a therapeutic substitution; or (2) requiring a prescription for a drug that is a nonformulary drug, requiring a co-payment or both.Amends the Public Health Service Act to require health insurance issuers in the individual market to offer health insurance coverage in the same manner as such coverage offered by a health insurance issuer in the group market.Amends the Public Health Service Act to require Medicare+Choice organizations to offer Medicare+choice plans in the same manner as such plans offer group health plans.Medicare+Choice Amendments - Amends the Public Health Service Act to add to the definition of "qualified health plan" for purposes of the Medicare+choice amendment any plan that is: (1) offered in the individual market; (2) offered in group market; and (3) maintained pursuant to a collective bargaining agreement between employee representatives and one or more employers ratified before enactment of this Act.Amends the Federal criminal code to repeal the prohibition against civil monetary penalties with respect to actions taken against persons who violate the laws of the United States or a State in which the Department of Justice (DOJ) operates.
summary_generated: Patients' Formulary Rights Act of 1999- Amends the Public Health Service Act and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) to prohibit a group health plan and a health insurance issuer offering group coverage from using a formulary unless the plan or issuer: (1) notifies participants, beneficiaries, and enrollees, prior to initial enrollment or coverage, and makes available at any time to health care professionals who prescribe prescription drugs under the plan or coverage; (2) notifies participants, beneficiaries, enrollees, and health care providers who prescribe covered prescription drugs under the plan or coverage on a routine and annual basis of any changes in the formulary; and (3) permits a participant, beneficiary, or enrollee who is provided coverage for a prescription drug at the time it is removed from the formulary to continue to have the drug prescribed for treatment of the same condition for which it was previously prescribed. <n>Directs that such provisions apply to coverage offered in the individual market.
